github.com

Git

Step 1 â€” Install apps
From Play Store install:


Obsidian


Termux (optional but helpful)



Step 2 â€” Download your vault from GitHub

Easiest way:

Open browser:

github.com/pravee-n2/Obsidian_Vault


Tap:

Code â†’ Download ZIP

Internal Storage/Documents/Obsidian/Office


Step 3 â€” Open vault in Obsidian mobile


Open Obsidian app


Tap:


Open folder as vault


Select:

Obsidian_Vault (the extracted folder)

Now your notes appear on mobile ğŸ‰

Step 4 â€” Install Git plugin in mobile Obsidian
Same as laptop:
Settings â†’ Community Plugins

Search:
Git

Install + Enable.

Step 5 â€” Set same sync settings
Set:

Auto pull on startup
Turn off pull feature in Auto commit and sync
Auto commit and sync manually when the editing ends.

Now phone will sync too.

Generate token for Repo

You must use:

GitHub username + Personal Access Token (PAT)

Think of PAT as a special Git password.

Why password wonâ€™t work
GitHub removed password authentication for security.
So:


âŒ GitHub password â†’ WILL FAIL


âœ… Personal Access Token â†’ WORKS



How to generate the correct token (2 minutes)
Do this on your laptop browser:

Open:

github.com/settings/tokens


Click:

Generate new token (classic)


Give name:

obsidian-mobile


Expiry:

No expiry

(or 1 year)

VERY IMPORTANT â€” Tick this:

repo  âœ…

Thatâ€™s enough.

Click:

Generate token


COPY the token immediately
(It will look like: ghp_xxxxxxxxxxxxx)

You cannot see it again later.

Now fill in mobile Obsidian
In the screen you showed:
Username:
(github_username)

Password/Personal access token:
Paste the token you generated.

Then do this
Restart Obsidian app.
Now try:


Pull


Commit & Sync


It should connect.

How to Generate PAT


What to select here
You already did most correctly:


Note: obsidian-mobile (type_your_desired_name) âœ”


Expiration: No expiration âœ” (ok for personal use)


Scope: repo âœ” VERY IMPORTANT


You donâ€™t need to tick anything else.

Now scroll down and click:
Generate token


VERY IMPORTANT STEP (Donâ€™t miss this)
After clicking generate, GitHub will show a long code like:
ghp_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

You must:


COPY it immediately


Save it somewhere temporarily


Because:

GitHub will NEVER show it again


Now go to your phone
In Obsidian Git settings:
Username:
(github_username)

Password / Personal Access Token:
Paste that token.
Then restart Obsidian app.

After restart, try this inside mobile Obsidian:
Open command palette (search icon) â†’ type:
Pull

Tap:
Git: Pull

If it connects â†’ mobile sync is ready.

Question: I used pull but it showed â€œCanâ€™t find a repository create one using the commandâ€
That error is expected ğŸ‘ â€” and it tells us exactly whatâ€™s wrong.

â€œCanâ€™t find a repositoryâ€ on mobile means:
Your phone vault folder does NOT contain the .git folder.

So the mobile app is seeing only notes, not the Git repo.
This usually happens if you:


Downloaded ZIP from GitHub
OR


Copied files manually


ZIP download does NOT include the .git directory.
And without .git, Git plugin cannot sync.

ğŸ”´ Why this happened
When you did:
Download ZIP
GitHub gives only files:
.md files folders
But NOT:
.git   âŒ (hidden repo data)
So Obsidian mobile says:

â€œNo repository foundâ€


You can directly copy the .git folder from laptop to phone.
This is the easiest non-technical method.

Why this works
Git plugin only needs one thing:
Vault folder must contain:    .git   â† repository data    .obsidian    notes
If .git is present â†’ mobile will detect repo instantly.
So instead of cloning on phone, you can just copy the full vault folder.

EASIEST METHOD
Step 1 â€” On laptop
Go to:
D:\(username)\Obsidian Vaults\Office
Copy the ENTIRE folder:
Office
Important: It must include: (Else, drill down to the folder and enable â€œVIEW HIDDEN ITEMSâ€ in File explorer, you will see .git folder, simply copy paste it into your Mobile Obsidian Folder)
.git      âœ” .obsidian âœ” Career Clippings Financial Modelling Miscellaneous

Step 2 â€” Send to phone
Any method is fine:


USB cable (best)


ShareIt


Nearby Share


Google Drive (zip and upload)


Paste it to phone inside:
Internal Storage/Documents/
So path becomes:
Documents/Office

Step 3 â€” Open in Obsidian mobile
Open Obsidian â†’ Open folder as vault â†’ select:
Documents/Office
Now Git plugin will detect repo automatically.

Step 4 â€” Enter credentials
In mobile Git plugin:
Username:
(github_username)
Password:
Paste the Personal Access Token.
Restart Obsidian once.

Step 5 â€” Test sync
Use command palette:
Git: Pull
Then:
Git: Commit & Sync
Should work.

VERY IMPORTANT WARNING âš ï¸
When copying from laptop:
Make sure hidden folders are visible.
Because .git is hidden.
If you only copy visible files, repo wonâ€™t work.
In Windows:
View â†’ Show â†’ Hidden items âœ”
Then copy.

How to set Author name for Commit?

Short answer:
ğŸ‘‰ Yes, use the SAME name and email as your desktop Git setup.

What to enter in each field
Username on your git server
Already correct:
(github_username)


Password / Personal access token
Paste the token you generated from GitHub:
ghp_xxxxxxxxxxxxxx


Author name for commit
Use the same name you set earlier on laptop.
Example:
Praveen

(or your full name if you used that)
This is just a label shown in commit history.

Author email for commit
Use the SAME email you used when configuring Git on laptop.
Example:
yourgithubemail@gmail.com

This should match the one you used in:
git config --global user.email


Why keeping same name/email is important
If you use different ones:


GitHub will show commits as from different people


History will look messy


Sync still works, but identity splits


If same:


All devices look like one user


Clean history



Summary
Fill like this:


Username â†’ (github_username)


Token â†’ (paste PAT)


Author name â†’ Praveen


Author email â†’ same GitHub email

GIT-setup-for-Obsidian/06-Commit-and-Syn.content:
You DONâ€™T have to manually press anything most of the time if you have enabled auto commit and sync.

When DO you need to manually press â€œCommit & Syncâ€?
Only in these cases:
1ï¸âƒ£ You want instant sync
Example:


You edited on mobile


Now going to open laptop immediately


Instead of waiting 10 min:
Tap â†’ Commit & Sync

Done instantly.

2ï¸âƒ£ Before closing Obsidian
Good habit:
Before closing app or shutting laptop:

So latest notes are safely pushed.

3ï¸âƒ£ When switching devices quickly
Example:


Edited on home laptop


Leaving for office in 2 minutes


Just press:
Commit & Sync

So office laptop gets latest version.

Think of it like WhatsApp

Best real-life workflow (simple)

Maybe once before closing:

On mobile:
When you finish editing:
Commit & Sync

Thatâ€™s enough.

One VERY important rule (remember this)
â— Never edit the SAME note on two devices at the same time.
Example BAD case:


Laptop editing note


Phone editing same note simultaneously


Git may create:
conflict copy

Just avoid parallel editing.

Auto commit and Sync settings

Simply enable these two settings. Note, turn off this feature
Pull on commit-and-sync. On commit-and-sync, pull commits as well. Turning this off turns a commit-and-sync action into commit and push only.
Reason, when you git auto commits and sync, it only pushes the data for the time being and we have already turned on Pull on startup, hence load will be reduced.

GIT-setup-for-Obsidian/07-Fixing-Obsidia.title: 07 Fixing Obsidian Git Sync Errors (Merge Conflicts, Pull, Push Issues & Multi-Device Setup Guide)
GIT-setup-for-Obsidian/07-Fixing-Obsidia.content:
If you use Obsidian with Git across multiple devices (home laptop, office laptop, mobile), you will eventually run into confusing errors like:


â€œConflicts detectedâ€


â€œYour local changes would be overwrittenâ€


â€œUpdates were rejected (fetch first)â€


Files showing <<<<<<< HEAD and >>>>>>> origin/main


Pull not working even after deleting files


This guide explains what these errors mean, why they happen, and how to fix them step-by-step. Itâ€™s written for beginners who just want their notes to sync safely.

1) Why These Errors Happen
These problems usually occur when:


You edit notes on Device A


You edit the same notes on Device B


Both versions are different


Git doesnâ€™t know which version to keep


So it stops and asks you to resolve the conflict.
This is not a bug. Itâ€™s Git protecting your data.

2) What a Merge Conflict Looks Like
You may see something like this inside a file:
<<<<<<< HEAD
My local changes
=======
Changes from GitHub
>>>>>>> origin/main

Meaning:


HEAD â†’ your current device version


origin/main â†’ GitHub version


Git is asking you which one to keep


You must remove these markers manually and choose the correct content.

3) If Remote Version Is Correct (Easiest Fix)
If GitHub has the correct notes and your laptop has outdated ones:
Safest method:


Discard local changes


Pull from GitHub


This makes your device match the remote version exactly.

4) If Git Gets Stuck in Merge State
Sometimes even after discarding, Git still says:


â€œUnmerged filesâ€


â€œMerge in progressâ€


Pull not working


That means Git is stuck halfway.
Clean fix:
Open Git Bash in your vault folder and run:
git reset --hard origin/main

This:


Removes conflict state


Deletes broken local changes


Makes your vault identical to GitHub


Your data on GitHub remains safe.

5) The BIGGEST Cause of Conflicts in Obsidian
Most conflicts are NOT from notes.
They come from device-specific files like:


.obsidian/workspace.json


.obsidian/app.json


.obsidian/plugins/obsidian-git/data.json


.obsidian/workspace-mobile.json


These files change on every device automatically.
So Git keeps detecting â€œchangesâ€.

6) Permanent Fix: Use .gitignore
You should stop syncing those files.
Create a .gitignore file in your vault and add:
.obsidian/workspace.json
.obsidian/workspace-mobile.json
.obsidian/app.json
.obsidian/plugins/obsidian-git/data.json

Then run:
git rm --cached .obsidian/workspace.json
git rm --cached .obsidian/workspace-mobile.json
git rm --cached .obsidian/app.json
git rm --cached .obsidian/plugins/obsidian-git/data.json
git add .gitignore
git commit -m "Ignore device-specific Obsidian files"
git push

This will:


Keep files locally


Stop syncing them


Prevent future conflicts


Important: Do NOT ignore the whole .obsidian folder.
It contains useful plugin and appearance settings that should sync.

7) Correct Obsidian Git Settings (Best for Multi-Device)
On all devices, use:


Pull on startup â†’ ON


Auto commit â†’ OFF


Pull on commit â†’ OFF


Push on commit â†’ ON (optional via Commit & Sync)


This setup gives you control and prevents background conflicts.

8) The Golden Workflow (Follow Forever)
Every time you open Obsidian:


Open Obsidian


Wait 5â€“10 seconds (let pull finish)


Start editing


When finished:

Press â€œCommit & Syncâ€

Thatâ€™s it.

9) NEVER Do This
Do NOT:


Edit immediately after opening


Push without pulling


Delete files during a merge


Force push unless you know what youâ€™re doing



10) Common Error Messages Explained
â€œUpdates were rejected (fetch first)â€
Meaning:
Remote has new changes.
You must pull before pushing.
Fix:
Pull â†’ then Commit & Sync


â€œYour local changes would be overwrittenâ€
Meaning:
Git sees local modified files.
Fix:


Discard changes


Pull again



Want to overwrite remote completely?
Only if youâ€™re 100% sure:
git push --force

Warning: This deletes remote history.

11) Clean Multi-Device Rule
Whether using:


Home laptop


Office laptop


Mobile


Always follow:
OPEN â†’ WAIT FOR PULL â†’ EDIT â†’ COMMIT & SYNC
If you follow just this one rule, conflicts almost disappear.

12) Final Result
After setting up properly:


Notes sync smoothly


Attachments sync


Plugins sync


Layout files stay local


Conflicts reduce drastically


Your Obsidian vault becomes stable across all devices.

13) Quick Recovery Checklist
If something breaks:


Close Obsidian


Open Git Bash in vault


Run:


git reset --hard origin/main

Reopen Obsidian.
Problem solved in most cases.

Conclusion
Using Git with Obsidian is extremely powerful, especially for multi-device syncing. But Git requires a small amount of discipline:


Always pull before editing


Avoid syncing device-specific files


Commit regularly


Once configured correctly, it becomes a reliable and professional sync system.
And the best part?
Your notes stay fully under your control.

GIT-setup-for-Obsidian/08-Quartz-Startup.title: 08 Quartz Startup Guide = From Obsidian Notes to a Fully Published Website (Step-by-Step + Real Mistakes & Fixes)
GIT-setup-for-Obsidian/08-Quartz-Startup.content:
This is a complete beginner-to-advanced setup guide for turning your Obsidian notes into a public website using Quartz + GitHub Pages.
This is not just a clean tutorial.
This guide is based on a real setup journey â€” including:


Every step from zero â†’ live website


Commands used at each stage


Errors that happened


Wrong turns and confusion moments


How each issue was diagnosed and fixed


Final stable workflow


If you follow this guide patiently, you will end up with:


ğŸŒ A fully online website


ğŸ“š Selected notes published publicly


ğŸ” Google-indexable pages


ğŸ†“ Free hosting forever


ğŸ’» Zero dependency on your system



ğŸ§­ What We Are Building (Big Picture)
We are creating an Obsidian-Publish alternative using this pipeline:
Obsidian Notes
      â†“
Git (version control)
      â†“
GitHub Repository
      â†“
Quartz (static site generator)
      â†“
GitHub Pages
      â†“
Public Website

This becomes your:


Knowledge base


Study portal


Blog


Personal documentation site


Long-term digital asset



ğŸªœ STEP 1 â€” Create a GitHub Repository
Go to GitHub and create a new repository.
Example name:
my-notes

Recommended settings:


Public repository


Can initialize with README (optional)


This repo will later host your website.

ğŸªœ STEP 2 â€” Upload Your Obsidian Vault to GitHub
Open Git Bash inside your vault folder and run:
git init
git remote add origin github.com/username/my-notes.git
git add .
git commit -m "first upload"
git push -u origin main

What this does:


Tracks your notes


Uploads them to GitHub


Creates version history


At this stage:
Your notes exist online â€” but not yet as a website.

ğŸªœ STEP 3 â€” Turn the Repo Into a Website (Basic Test)
Go to:
Repo â†’ Settings â†’ Pages

Set:
Source: Deploy from branch
Branch: main
Folder: /root

GitHub will give a link like:
username.github.io/my-notes/

This confirms:


GitHub Pages is working


Hosting is active


BUT:
It will only show files â€” not a real website.
Thatâ€™s where Quartz comes in.

ğŸªœ STEP 4 â€” Install Quartz (Website Engine)
Quartz converts markdown notes into a real website with:


Navigation


Dark mode


Backlinks


Graph


Search


SEO structure


First Attempt (Common Beginner Error)
Tried installing using:
git clone github.com/jackyzha0/quartz .

Error received:
fatal: destination path '.' already exists

Why?
Because the vault folder already had files inside it.
Fix
Instead:


Download Quartz ZIP


Extract it


Copy files manually into the project folder



ğŸªœ STEP 5 â€” Another Mistake: Wrong Folder Placement
Quartz got extracted as:
Obsidian_Vault/quartz-4/

This is incorrect.
Correct structure should be:
Obsidian_Vault/
  notes...
  quartz/
  package.json
  quartz.config.ts

Fix:
Move all Quartz files to the root.

ğŸªœ STEP 6 â€” Install Node.js (Required)
Quartz requires Node.js.
Install from official site.
Then verify:
node -v
npm -v

If both show version numbers â†’ ready.

ğŸªœ STEP 7 â€” Install Dependencies
Inside the Quartz folder:
npm install
npx quartz build

This creates:
public/

Important concept:
public = the generated website

ğŸªœ STEP 8 â€” Major Structural Decision (Very Important)
At first, Quartz was inside the main vault.
Problem:


Obsidian started showing system files


Vault looked cluttered


Hard to manage


Better Architecture (Recommended)
Obsidian_Vault/   â†’ private notes
quartz-site/      â†’ website engine

This keeps:


Writing clean


Publishing controlled


Structure professional



ğŸªœ STEP 9 â€” Understanding Quartz Content Logic
Quartz publishes ONLY what is inside:
content/

Meaning:
You control what goes public.
Smart strategy:
Private vault â†’ everything
content/ â†’ selected polished notes

ğŸªœ STEP 10 â€” First Build Error
Mistake:
Ran command inside wrong directory:
/quartz-site/content

Error:
ENOENT: package.json not found

Fix:
Move one level up:
cd ..
npx quartz build

Lesson:
Always run Quartz commands where package.json exists.

ğŸªœ STEP 11 â€” Preview Locally
Quartz v4 command:
npx quartz build --serve

Then open:
http://localhost:8080

At first â†’ 404 page.

ğŸªœ STEP 12 â€” Critical Rule: Homepage Must Be index.md
Quartz requires:
content/index.md

Without it:
â†’ Site shows 404
Fix:
Create:
index.md


ğŸªœ STEP 13 â€” Windows Extension Trap
File looked like:
index.md

But actually:
index.md.txt

Windows hides extensions.
Fix:
Enable â€œShow file extensionsâ€
Rename properly.

ğŸªœ STEP 14 â€” Custom Page Title
Add frontmatter at top:
---
title: My Knowledge Hub
---

This replaces the default â€œindexâ€ title.

ğŸªœ STEP 15 â€” Push Website to GitHub
Inside quartz-site:
git init
git add .
